trans-unit.source: Frequently Asked Questions
trans-unit.target: Frequently Asked Questions

trans-unit.source: What is a PowerShell module?
trans-unit.target: What is a PowerShell module?

trans-unit.source: A PowerShell module is a reusable package containing some PowerShell functionality.
trans-unit.target: A PowerShell module is a reusable package containing some PowerShell functionality.

trans-unit.source: Everything in PowerShell (functions, variables, DSC resources, etc.) can be packaged in modules.
trans-unit.target: Everything in PowerShell (functions, variables, DSC resources, etc.) can be packaged in modules.

trans-unit.source: Typically, modules are folders containing specific types of files stored on a specific path.
trans-unit.target: Typically, modules are folders containing specific types of files stored on a specific path.

trans-unit.source: There are a few different types of PowerShell modules out there.
trans-unit.target: There are a few different types of PowerShell modules out there.

trans-unit.source: What is a PowerShell script?
trans-unit.target: What is a PowerShell script?

trans-unit.source: A PowerShell script is a series of commands that are stored in a .ps1 file to enable reuse and sharing.
trans-unit.target: A PowerShell script is a series of commands that are stored in a .ps1 file to enable reuse and sharing.

trans-unit.source: PowerShell workflows are also PowerShell scripts, which outline a set of tasks and provide sequencing for those tasks.
trans-unit.target: PowerShell workflows are also PowerShell scripts, which outline a set of tasks and provide sequencing for those tasks.

trans-unit.source: For more information, please visit [Getting Started with PowerShell Workflow](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj134242.aspx).
trans-unit.target: For more information, please visit [Getting Started with PowerShell Workflow](https://technet.microsoft.com/en-us/library/jj134242.aspx).

trans-unit.source: How are PowerShell Scripts different from PowerShell Modules?
trans-unit.target: How are PowerShell Scripts different from PowerShell Modules?

trans-unit.source: Modules are generally better for sharing, but we are enabling script sharing to make it easier for you to contribute workflows and scripts to the community.
trans-unit.target: Modules are generally better for sharing, but we are enabling script sharing to make it easier for you to contribute workflows and scripts to the community.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see the following blogs:
trans-unit.target: For more information, see the following blogs:

trans-unit.source: [Don't Write Scripts, Write PowerShell Modules](http://blogs.technet.com/b/heyscriptingguy/archive/2011/06/27/don-t-write-scripts-write-powershell-modules.aspx)
trans-unit.target: [Don't Write Scripts, Write PowerShell Modules](http://blogs.technet.com/b/heyscriptingguy/archive/2011/06/27/don-t-write-scripts-write-powershell-modules.aspx)

trans-unit.source: [Understanding PowerShell Modules](http://blogs.technet.com/b/heyscriptingguy/archive/2015/07/10/understanding-powershell-modules.aspx)
trans-unit.target: [Understanding PowerShell Modules](http://blogs.technet.com/b/heyscriptingguy/archive/2015/07/10/understanding-powershell-modules.aspx)

trans-unit.source: How can I publish to the PowerShell Gallery?
trans-unit.target: How can I publish to the PowerShell Gallery?

trans-unit.source: You must register an account in the PowerShell Gallery before you can publish items to the Gallery.
trans-unit.target: You must register an account in the PowerShell Gallery before you can publish items to the Gallery.

trans-unit.source: This is because publishing items requires a NuGetApiKey, which is provided upon registration.
trans-unit.target: This is because publishing items requires a NuGetApiKey, which is provided upon registration.

trans-unit.source: To register, use your personal, work, or school account to sign in to the PowerShell Gallery.
trans-unit.target: To register, use your personal, work, or school account to sign in to the PowerShell Gallery.

trans-unit.source: A one-time registration process is required when you sign in for the first time.
trans-unit.target: A one-time registration process is required when you sign in for the first time.

trans-unit.source: Afterwards, your NuGetApiKey is available on your profile page.
trans-unit.target: Afterwards, your NuGetApiKey is available on your profile page.

trans-unit.source: Once you have registered in the Gallery, use the [Publish-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) or [Publish-Script](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlets to publish your item to the Gallery.
trans-unit.target: Once you have registered in the Gallery, use the [Publish-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) or [Publish-Script](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlets to publish your item to the Gallery.

trans-unit.source: For more details on how to run these cmdlets, visit the Publish tab, or read the [Publish-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) and [Publish-Script](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) documentation.
trans-unit.target: For more details on how to run these cmdlets, visit the Publish tab, or read the [Publish-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) and [Publish-Script](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) documentation.

trans-unit.source: **You do not need to register or sign in to the Gallery to install or save items.**
trans-unit.target: **You do not need to register or sign in to the Gallery to install or save items.**

trans-unit.source: I received "Failed to process request.
trans-unit.target: I received "Failed to process request.

trans-unit.source: 'The specified API key is invalid or does not have permission to access the specified package.'.
trans-unit.target: 'The specified API key is invalid or does not have permission to access the specified package.'.

trans-unit.source: The remote server returned an error: (403) Forbidden."
trans-unit.target: The remote server returned an error: (403) Forbidden."

trans-unit.source: error when I tried to publish an item to the PowerShell Gallery.
trans-unit.target: error when I tried to publish an item to the PowerShell Gallery.

trans-unit.source: What does that mean?
trans-unit.target: What does that mean?

trans-unit.source: This error can occur for the following reasons:
trans-unit.target: This error can occur for the following reasons:

trans-unit.source: **The specified API key is invalid.**
trans-unit.target: **The specified API key is invalid.**

trans-unit.source: Ensure that you have specified the valid API key from your account.
trans-unit.target: Ensure that you have specified the valid API key from your account.

trans-unit.source: To get your API key, view your profile page.
trans-unit.target: To get your API key, view your profile page.

trans-unit.source: **The specified item name is not owned by you.**
trans-unit.target: **The specified item name is not owned by you.**

trans-unit.source: If you have confirmed that your API key is correct, then there may already exist an item with the same name as the one you are trying to use.
trans-unit.target: If you have confirmed that your API key is correct, then there may already exist an item with the same name as the one you are trying to use.

trans-unit.source: The item may have been unlisted by the owner, in which case it will not appear in any search results.
trans-unit.target: The item may have been unlisted by the owner, in which case it will not appear in any search results.

trans-unit.source: To determine if an item with the same name already exists, open a browser and navigate to the item's details page: `https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/<itemName>`.
trans-unit.target: To determine if an item with the same name already exists, open a browser and navigate to the item's details page: `https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/<itemName>`.

trans-unit.source: For example, navigating directly to `https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/pester` will take you to the Pester module's details page, whether it is unlisted or not.
trans-unit.target: For example, navigating directly to `https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages/pester` will take you to the Pester module's details page, whether it is unlisted or not.

trans-unit.source: If an item with a conflicting name already exists and is unlisted, you can:
trans-unit.target: If an item with a conflicting name already exists and is unlisted, you can:

trans-unit.source: Select another name for your item.
trans-unit.target: Select another name for your item.

trans-unit.source: Contact the owners of the existing item.
trans-unit.target: Contact the owners of the existing item.

trans-unit.source: Why can't I sign in with my personal account, but I could sign in yesterday?
trans-unit.target: Why can't I sign in with my personal account, but I could sign in yesterday?

trans-unit.source: Please be aware that your gallery account does not accommodate changes to your primary email alias.
trans-unit.target: Please be aware that your gallery account does not accommodate changes to your primary email alias.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see [Microsoft Email Aliases](http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/outlook/add-alias-account).
trans-unit.target: For more information, see [Microsoft Email Aliases](http://windows.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/outlook/add-alias-account).

trans-unit.source: Why don't I see all the gallery items when I select all the Category checkboxes on the Items tab?
trans-unit.target: Why don't I see all the gallery items when I select all the Category checkboxes on the Items tab?

trans-unit.source: By selecting a Category checkbox, you are stating "I would like to see all items in this category."
trans-unit.target: By selecting a Category checkbox, you are stating "I would like to see all items in this category."

trans-unit.source: Only the items in the selected categories will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: Only the items in the selected categories will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: So similarly, by selecting all the Category checkboxes, you are stating "I would like to see all items in any category."
trans-unit.target: So similarly, by selecting all the Category checkboxes, you are stating "I would like to see all items in any category."

trans-unit.source: But some items in the gallery do not belong to any of the categories listed, so they will not appear in the results.
trans-unit.target: But some items in the gallery do not belong to any of the categories listed, so they will not appear in the results.

trans-unit.source: To see all items in the gallery, uncheck all the Categories, or select the Items tab again.
trans-unit.target: To see all items in the gallery, uncheck all the Categories, or select the Items tab again.

trans-unit.source: What are the requirements to publish a module to the PowerShell Gallery?
trans-unit.target: What are the requirements to publish a module to the PowerShell Gallery?

trans-unit.source: Any kind of PowerShell module (script modules, binary modules, or manifest modules) can be published to the gallery.
trans-unit.target: Any kind of PowerShell module (script modules, binary modules, or manifest modules) can be published to the gallery.

trans-unit.source: To publish a module, PowerShellGet needs to know a few things about it - the version, description, author, and how it is licensed.
trans-unit.target: To publish a module, PowerShellGet needs to know a few things about it - the version, description, author, and how it is licensed.

trans-unit.source: This information is read as part of the publishing process from the *module manifest* (.psd1) file, or from the value of the [**Publish-Module**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet's **LicenseUri** parameter.
trans-unit.target: This information is read as part of the publishing process from the *module manifest* (.psd1) file, or from the value of the [**Publish-Module**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet's **LicenseUri** parameter.

trans-unit.source: All modules published to the Gallery must have module manifests.
trans-unit.target: All modules published to the Gallery must have module manifests.

trans-unit.source: Any module that includes the following information in its manifest can be published to the Gallery:
trans-unit.target: Any module that includes the following information in its manifest can be published to the Gallery:

trans-unit.source: Version
trans-unit.target: Version

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Author
trans-unit.target: Author

trans-unit.source: A URI to the license terms of the module, either as part of the **PrivateData** section of the manifest, or in the **LicenseUri** parameter of the [**Publish-Module**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: A URI to the license terms of the module, either as part of the **PrivateData** section of the manifest, or in the **LicenseUri** parameter of the [**Publish-Module**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: How do I create a correctly-formatted module manifest?
trans-unit.target: How do I create a correctly-formatted module manifest?

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to create a module manifest is to run the [**New-ModuleManifest**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to create a module manifest is to run the [**New-ModuleManifest**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In PowerShell 5.0 or newer, New-ModuleManifest generates a correctly-formatted module manifest with blank fields for useful metadata like **ProjectUri**, **LicenseUri**, and **Tags**.
trans-unit.target: In PowerShell 5.0 or newer, New-ModuleManifest generates a correctly-formatted module manifest with blank fields for useful metadata like **ProjectUri**, **LicenseUri**, and **Tags**.

trans-unit.source: Simply fill in the blanks, or use the generated manifest as an example of correct formatting.
trans-unit.target: Simply fill in the blanks, or use the generated manifest as an example of correct formatting.

trans-unit.source: To verify that all required metadata fields have been properly filled, use the [**Test-ModuleManifest**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To verify that all required metadata fields have been properly filled, use the [**Test-ModuleManifest**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: To update the module manifest file fields, use the [**Update-ModuleManifest**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To update the module manifest file fields, use the [**Update-ModuleManifest**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: What are the requirements to publish a script to the Gallery?
trans-unit.target: What are the requirements to publish a script to the Gallery?

trans-unit.source: Any kind of PowerShell script (scripts or workflows) can be published to the gallery.
trans-unit.target: Any kind of PowerShell script (scripts or workflows) can be published to the gallery.

trans-unit.source: To publish a script, PowerShellGet needs to know a few things about it - the version, description, author, and how it is licensed.
trans-unit.target: To publish a script, PowerShellGet needs to know a few things about it - the version, description, author, and how it is licensed.

trans-unit.source: This information is read as part of the publishing process from the script file's *PSScriptInfo* section, or from the value of the [**Publish-Script**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet's **LicenseUri** parameter.
trans-unit.target: This information is read as part of the publishing process from the script file's *PSScriptInfo* section, or from the value of the [**Publish-Script**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet's **LicenseUri** parameter.

trans-unit.source: All scripts published to the Gallery must have metadata information.
trans-unit.target: All scripts published to the Gallery must have metadata information.

trans-unit.source: Any script that includes the following information in its PSScriptInfo section can be published to the Gallery:
trans-unit.target: Any script that includes the following information in its PSScriptInfo section can be published to the Gallery:

trans-unit.source: Version
trans-unit.target: Version

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Author
trans-unit.target: Author

trans-unit.source: A URI to the license terms of the script, either as part of the **PSScriptInfo** section of the script, or in the **LicenseUri** parameter of the [**Publish-Script**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: A URI to the license terms of the script, either as part of the **PSScriptInfo** section of the script, or in the **LicenseUri** parameter of the [**Publish-Script**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: How do I search?
trans-unit.target: How do I search?

trans-unit.source: Type what you are looking for in the text box.
trans-unit.target: Type what you are looking for in the text box.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you want to find modules that are related to Azure SQL, just type "azure sql".
trans-unit.target: For example, if you want to find modules that are related to Azure SQL, just type "azure sql".

trans-unit.source: Our search engine will look for those keywords in all published items, including titles, descriptions and across metadata.
trans-unit.target: Our search engine will look for those keywords in all published items, including titles, descriptions and across metadata.

trans-unit.source: Then, based on a weighted quality score, it will display the closest matches.
trans-unit.target: Then, based on a weighted quality score, it will display the closest matches.

trans-unit.source: You can also search by specific field using field:"value" syntax in the search query for the following fields:
trans-unit.target: You can also search by specific field using field:"value" syntax in the search query for the following fields:

trans-unit.source: Tags
trans-unit.target: Tags

trans-unit.source: Functions
trans-unit.target: Functions

trans-unit.source: Cmdlets
trans-unit.target: Cmdlets

trans-unit.source: DscResources
trans-unit.target: DscResources

trans-unit.source: PowerShellVersion
trans-unit.target: PowerShellVersion

trans-unit.source: So, for example, when you search for PowerShellVersion:"2.0" only results that are compatible with PowerShellVersion 2.0 (based on their module/script manifest) will be displayed.
trans-unit.target: So, for example, when you search for PowerShellVersion:"2.0" only results that are compatible with PowerShellVersion 2.0 (based on their module/script manifest) will be displayed.

trans-unit.source: How do I create a correctly-formatted script file?
trans-unit.target: How do I create a correctly-formatted script file?

trans-unit.source: The easiest way to create a properly-formatted script file is to run the [**New-ScriptFileInfo**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: The easiest way to create a properly-formatted script file is to run the [**New-ScriptFileInfo**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: In PowerShell 5.0, New-ScriptFileInfo generates a correctly-formatted script file with blank fields for useful metadata like **ProjectUri**, **LicenseUri**, and **Tags**.
trans-unit.target: In PowerShell 5.0, New-ScriptFileInfo generates a correctly-formatted script file with blank fields for useful metadata like **ProjectUri**, **LicenseUri**, and **Tags**.

trans-unit.source: Simply fill in the blanks, or use the generated script file as an example of correct formatting.
trans-unit.target: Simply fill in the blanks, or use the generated script file as an example of correct formatting.

trans-unit.source: To verify that all required metadata fields have been properly filled, use the [**Test-ScriptFileInfo**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To verify that all required metadata fields have been properly filled, use the [**Test-ScriptFileInfo**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: To update the script metadata fields, use the [**Update-ScriptFileInfo**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: To update the script metadata fields, use the [**Update-ScriptFileInfo**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: What other types of PowerShell Modules exist?
trans-unit.target: What other types of PowerShell Modules exist?

trans-unit.source: The term PowerShell module also refers to the files that implement actual functionality.
trans-unit.target: The term PowerShell module also refers to the files that implement actual functionality.

trans-unit.source: Script module files (.psm1) contain PowerShell code.
trans-unit.target: Script module files (.psm1) contain PowerShell code.

trans-unit.source: Binary module files (.dll) contain compiled code.
trans-unit.target: Binary module files (.dll) contain compiled code.

trans-unit.source: Here is one way to think about it: the folder that encapsulates the module is the module folder.
trans-unit.target: Here is one way to think about it: the folder that encapsulates the module is the module folder.

trans-unit.source: The module folder can contain a module manifest (.psd1) that describes the contents of the folder.
trans-unit.target: The module folder can contain a module manifest (.psd1) that describes the contents of the folder.

trans-unit.source: The files that actually do the work are the script module files (.psm1) and the binary module files (.dll).
trans-unit.target: The files that actually do the work are the script module files (.psm1) and the binary module files (.dll).

trans-unit.source: DSC resources are located in a specific sub-folder, and are implemented as script module files or binary module files.
trans-unit.target: DSC resources are located in a specific sub-folder, and are implemented as script module files or binary module files.

trans-unit.source: All of the modules in the Gallery contain module manifests, and most of these modules contain script module files or binary module files.
trans-unit.target: All of the modules in the Gallery contain module manifests, and most of these modules contain script module files or binary module files.

trans-unit.source: The term module can be confusing because of these different meanings.
trans-unit.target: The term module can be confusing because of these different meanings.

trans-unit.source: Unless explicitly stated otherwise, all uses of the word module on this page refer to the module folder containing these files.
trans-unit.target: Unless explicitly stated otherwise, all uses of the word module on this page refer to the module folder containing these files.

trans-unit.source: How does PackageManagement relate to PowerShellGet?
trans-unit.target: How does PackageManagement relate to PowerShellGet?

trans-unit.source: (High Level Answer)
trans-unit.target: (High Level Answer)

trans-unit.source: PackageManagement is a common interface for working with any package manager.
trans-unit.target: PackageManagement is a common interface for working with any package manager.

trans-unit.source: Eventually, whether you're dealing with PowerShell modules, MSIs, Ruby gems, NuGet packages, or Perl modules, you should be able to use PackageManagement's commands (Find-Package and Install-Package) to find and install them.
trans-unit.target: Eventually, whether you're dealing with PowerShell modules, MSIs, Ruby gems, NuGet packages, or Perl modules, you should be able to use PackageManagement's commands (Find-Package and Install-Package) to find and install them.

trans-unit.source: PackageManagement does this by having a package provider for each package manager that plugs into PackageManagement.
trans-unit.target: PackageManagement does this by having a package provider for each package manager that plugs into PackageManagement.

trans-unit.source: Providers do all of the actual work; they fetch content from repositories, and install the content locally.
trans-unit.target: Providers do all of the actual work; they fetch content from repositories, and install the content locally.

trans-unit.source: Often, package providers simply wrap around the existing package manager tools for a given package type.
trans-unit.target: Often, package providers simply wrap around the existing package manager tools for a given package type.

trans-unit.source: PowerShellGet is the package manager for PowerShell items.
trans-unit.target: PowerShellGet is the package manager for PowerShell items.

trans-unit.source: There is a PSModule package provider that exposes PowerShellGet functionality through PackageManagement.
trans-unit.target: There is a PSModule package provider that exposes PowerShellGet functionality through PackageManagement.

trans-unit.source: Because of this, you can either run [Install-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) or Install-Package -Provider PSModule to install a module from the PowerShell Gallery.
trans-unit.target: Because of this, you can either run [Install-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) or Install-Package -Provider PSModule to install a module from the PowerShell Gallery.

trans-unit.source: Certain PowerShellGet functionality, including [Update-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) and [Publish-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409), cannot be accessed through PackageManagement commands.
trans-unit.target: Certain PowerShellGet functionality, including [Update-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) and [Publish-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409), cannot be accessed through PackageManagement commands.

trans-unit.source: In summary, PowerShellGet is solely focused on having a premium package management experience for PowerShell content.
trans-unit.target: In summary, PowerShellGet is solely focused on having a premium package management experience for PowerShell content.

trans-unit.source: PackageManagement is focused on exposing all package management experiences through one general set of tools.
trans-unit.target: PackageManagement is focused on exposing all package management experiences through one general set of tools.

trans-unit.source: If you find this answer unsatisfying, there is a long answer at the bottom of this document, in the **How does PackageManagement actually relate to PowerShellGet?** section.
trans-unit.target: If you find this answer unsatisfying, there is a long answer at the bottom of this document, in the **How does PackageManagement actually relate to PowerShellGet?** section.

trans-unit.source: For more information, please visit the [PackageManagement project page](http://oneget.org/).
trans-unit.target: For more information, please visit the [PackageManagement project page](http://oneget.org/).

trans-unit.source: How does NuGet relate to PowerShellGet?
trans-unit.target: How does NuGet relate to PowerShellGet?

trans-unit.source: The PowerShell Gallery is a modified version of the [NuGet Gallery](http://www.nuget.org/).
trans-unit.target: The PowerShell Gallery is a modified version of the [NuGet Gallery](http://www.nuget.org/).

trans-unit.source: PowerShellGet uses NuGet provider to work with NuGet based repositories like the PowerShell Gallery.
trans-unit.target: PowerShellGet uses NuGet provider to work with NuGet based repositories like the PowerShell Gallery.

trans-unit.source: You can use PowerShellGet against any valid NuGet repository or file share.
trans-unit.target: You can use PowerShellGet against any valid NuGet repository or file share.

trans-unit.source: You simply need to add the repository by running the [**Register-PSRepository**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.
trans-unit.target: You simply need to add the repository by running the [**Register-PSRepository**](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) cmdlet.

trans-unit.source: Does that mean I can use NuGet.exe to work with the Gallery?
trans-unit.target: Does that mean I can use NuGet.exe to work with the Gallery?

trans-unit.source: Yes.
trans-unit.target: Yes.

trans-unit.source: How does PackageManagement actually relate to PowerShellGet?
trans-unit.target: How does PackageManagement actually relate to PowerShellGet?

trans-unit.source: (Technical Details)
trans-unit.target: (Technical Details)

trans-unit.source: Under the hood, PowerShellGet heavily leverages PackageManagement infrastructure.
trans-unit.target: Under the hood, PowerShellGet heavily leverages PackageManagement infrastructure.

trans-unit.source: At the PowerShell cmdlet layer, [Install-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) is actually a thin wrapper around Install-Package -Provider PSModule.
trans-unit.target: At the PowerShell cmdlet layer, [Install-Module](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=760387&clcid=0x409) is actually a thin wrapper around Install-Package -Provider PSModule.

trans-unit.source: At the PackageManagement package provider layer, the PSModule package provider actually calls into other PackageManagement package providers.
trans-unit.target: At the PackageManagement package provider layer, the PSModule package provider actually calls into other PackageManagement package providers.

trans-unit.source: For example, when you are working with NuGet-based galleries (such as the PowerShell Gallery), the PSModule package provider uses the NuGet Package Provider to work with the repository.
trans-unit.target: For example, when you are working with NuGet-based galleries (such as the PowerShell Gallery), the PSModule package provider uses the NuGet Package Provider to work with the repository.

trans-unit.source: PowerShellGet Architecture
trans-unit.target: PowerShellGet Architecture

trans-unit.source: Figure 1: PowerShellGet Architecture
trans-unit.target: Figure 1: PowerShellGet Architecture

trans-unit.source: What is required to run PowerShellGet?
trans-unit.target: What is required to run PowerShellGet?

trans-unit.source: In general we recommend picking the latest version of PowerShellGet module (note that it requires .NET 4.5).
trans-unit.target: In general we recommend picking the latest version of PowerShellGet module (note that it requires .NET 4.5).

trans-unit.source: The **PowerShellGet** module requires **PowerShell 3.0 or newer**.
trans-unit.target: The **PowerShellGet** module requires **PowerShell 3.0 or newer**.

trans-unit.source: Therefore, **PowerShellGet** requires one of the following operating systems:
trans-unit.target: Therefore, **PowerShellGet** requires one of the following operating systems:

trans-unit.source: Windows 10
trans-unit.target: Windows 10

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1 Pro
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 Pro

trans-unit.source: Windows 8.1 Enterprise
trans-unit.target: Windows 8.1 Enterprise

trans-unit.source: Windows 7 SP1
trans-unit.target: Windows 7 SP1

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2016
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2016

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2012 R2
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2012 R2

trans-unit.source: Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1
trans-unit.target: Windows Server 2008 R2 SP1

trans-unit.source: **PowerShellGet** also requires .NET Framework 4.5 or above.
trans-unit.target: **PowerShellGet** also requires .NET Framework 4.5 or above.

trans-unit.source: You can install .NET Framework 4.5 or above from [here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/5a4x27ek.aspx).
trans-unit.target: You can install .NET Framework 4.5 or above from [here](https://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/5a4x27ek.aspx).

trans-unit.source: Is it possible to reserve names for items that will be published in future?
trans-unit.target: Is it possible to reserve names for items that will be published in future?

trans-unit.source: It is not possible to squat item names.
trans-unit.target: It is not possible to squat item names.

trans-unit.source: If you feel that an existing item has taken the name which suits your item more, try [contacting the owner of the item](psgallery_contacting_item_owners.md).
trans-unit.target: If you feel that an existing item has taken the name which suits your item more, try [contacting the owner of the item](psgallery_contacting_item_owners.md).

trans-unit.source: If you didnt get response within a couple of weeks, you can contact support and the PowerShell Gallery team will look in to it.
trans-unit.target: If you didnt get response within a couple of weeks, you can contact support and the PowerShell Gallery team will look in to it.

trans-unit.source: How do I claim ownership for items ?
trans-unit.target: How do I claim ownership for items ?

trans-unit.source: Check out [Managing Item Owners on PowerShellGallery.com](Managing-Item-Owners.md) for details.
trans-unit.target: Check out [Managing Item Owners on PowerShellGallery.com](Managing-Item-Owners.md) for details.

trans-unit.source: How do I deal with an item owner who is violating my item license?
trans-unit.target: How do I deal with an item owner who is violating my item license?

trans-unit.source: We encourage the PowerShell community to work together to resolve any disputes that may arise between item owners and the owners of other items.
trans-unit.target: We encourage the PowerShell community to work together to resolve any disputes that may arise between item owners and the owners of other items.

trans-unit.source: We have crafted a [dispute resolution process](psgallery_dispute_resolution.md) that we ask you to follow before PowerShellGallery.com administrators intercede.
trans-unit.target: We have crafted a [dispute resolution process](psgallery_dispute_resolution.md) that we ask you to follow before PowerShellGallery.com administrators intercede.
